William - she says she thinks she has served her country well by giving it 6 sons- Mary Bureau took my pictures down one evening to entertain her uncle Will who is still hanging on to life by a very slender thread and they all thought them beautiful - concluded you must have a lovely place - Mr Wills writes to Charlotte that Sarah is in Washington and he thinks there is a marriage on the unclear but add this is private - Genl. Keyes of the Army was the last canvasser I heard of - I don't know whether I told you - she was boarding in N.Y. Romy goes to school to Miss James, daughter of the novelist - and Vinton to some Catholic school.  I had a letter from Frank he is well and expects to be very busy having taken 2 or 3 extras -

So, you are really discouraged about the war, well it looks rather dark - but I feel that my Father's at the helm.  We have greatly sinned and must receive the measure of our punishment- or rather what will make us do better for our full measure would annihilate us.- had Lincoln issued a proclamation of emancipation based on principles of justice and mercy, and not on a military necessity - we might have expected to have the Lord on our side and who can withstand the Almighty should the Union be sent asunder and slavery abolished there will be great pain to the moral universe- It becomes us to pray without ceasing - that freedom and righteousness may be established - as Charlotte has received your letter she may wish to enclose the receipt - Much love to you all my very dear children - whatever may happen in the world may God Help and prepare you for eternity  as ever, your ever loving and devoted Mother -

Ma
Rec'd Nov 16/1862
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois -

Very dear Johnny -  I have a kind of feeling when I am alone that I ought to be writing to my dear absent ones - so I will say a few words to you this evening merely by way of throwing you a few thoughts and musings - a very strange and unaccountable thing to me is the impressions produced upon the mind by photographs - it has often happened to me at first sight to condemn a picture and afterwards think it very good just now in looking over Sis' album I came across your face and it struck me as particularly good, soft, and beautiful and Julia's, as being pretty good too, but not as pretty as the original - and the first time I saw them.  I did not recognise them at all - so, once, with one of Romaine that I did not know, I became to consider excellent - Jane is home - and I really think, much better and brighter - we are getting along pretty well now, with an occasional hint about economy and the hardness of the times

which I cannot think out of place for my own mind has run much in that direction for some time - I know there must be much suffering among the poor this winter- everything is so high and work so scarce - but I do not think the rich ought to economise - they should employ the poor and give high wages - it is more truly benevolent to give high wages than to bestow charity - where people can work I really feel as tho our war prospects were brightening - the elections notwitstanding- if Lincoln does all in his power for the remainder of his term it will not matter what party is in power - and this defeat will certainly stimulate him to vigorous action - a report comes that McCLellan is suspended? I am glad of that - he would have draggged us thro' another winter - I did not suspect his loyalty before but thought him very incapable - now I begin to think him a coward or a traitor - he certainly has permitted (if not worse) a very great and unmerciful

slaughter of men - to say nothing of the sickness and deaths in camp by delay - but no atter are beginning to improve-  I was disappointed yesterday (Wednesday) in not getting two letters, but perhaps they will come today.  I hear that Frank is studying hard.  Julius has been looking round at farms but I told him to be patient he would have an offer of the one he is on - so it has proved there is some kind of negotiation on foot that may result in his remaining - but as Mr. Kuhn insists on his being entirely independent I think he can manage matters better then heretofore - Annie  would like very well to remain - in a right way - Mr Kuhn intends to stock the farm and before long to gibe them one - Sis & Mary Bureau are gone out this morning on foot to be back tomorrow it is a delightful day - and I took the children along as far as the top of the hill - we gathered beautiful leaves - and enjoyed our walk - I think I  should soon be sick if I could not go out.  poor Mrs Ward is here

and I think she has bronchitis - and I don't believe she will ever be any better- Will Hughes still keeps about tho very thin & feeble -  Pa is stiff & coughs a god deal but rides out to his farms very often and is quite well - do you know our young set - Jim Wilson is to be married to Mary Leet she is the last of her family and was brought up by Mrs Cook - Jim works hard and is making money with his nursery - Ed is in the army - in the Anderson Troup -  Much love to you all my very dear children from your truly loving Mother -

Ma
Recd Nov 21. 1862
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois

Nov 17"  for 17 
Dear Johnny-
As this was intended to be written yesterday perhaps it should be so dated but I could not help feeling that it ought not bear a lie on its face - So another year is added to your term of service - about the birth days come often - and how do they compare with each other - as we grow in years should we not grow in wisdom and goodness - should we not ripen for a better holier state - alas and do we?  I fear our bodies ripen faster than souls - and that is the sad part of our progress - dear Johnny may you grow in grace and wisdom and goodness as you grow in years - and may you finish your course in joy and peace - and your children bless your memory - My children are my greatest earthly blessings and if I had them all around me I fear I should become contracted and forget my duties to the work - as it is I am surrounded with blessings and

receive my trials as necessary assignments to keep me in the right way - Julius was in yesterday - and in trouble, tho Pa has had the accounts & books for sone time he is not yet ready to settle and poor Julius cannot get enough to pay his debts - you don't know how glad I was that I was here to comfort and help him - dry his tears, encourage him, and lend him money for present use - I made him promise to cheer up and not mind these things since he is very happy in his family which you know is the principal thing - besides since Mr. Kuhn is inclined to help them they have a good prospect before them - but Julius is decided not to remain on Pa's farm - I read your letter to him - but I think they would both rather stay here -  Pa has sold his Monongahela farm.  I dont know how much he got for it - yes I have just heard 10.000 -

I'll make no comment lest I should be personal - in patience let us progress our souls - God will do us good if we trust in him - I have put so much confidence in man but God is delivering me - and will do all things well -  I hope you are feeling a little better about the war - now that McClellan is out of the way I think we shall certainly move - What a clog he has been - I did not before doubt his loyalty - but I am beginning to think there is something wrong about - it may have been electioneering whatever it was. at what a cost of life and money & honor. was it pursued - Our clouds are at least growing thin if they are not dispelling - as to the elections, they were most opportunely fortunate - to open the eyes of Lincoln to the impolicy? of trying to please the democrats.  let him now pressure a just liberal and energetic policy and all will be well - and free  Frank says the excitement in Philadelphia was intense - but Phila is intensely proud

and aristocratic - so I think is McClellan there is too much of that in our country - it must be broken up.  next move ought to reinstate Fremont.  We should be very glad indeed to see Julia but cannot recommend the trip over a rough road, of 8 hours length.  Much love to you all - I did intend scolding you about making such country takes of your children - I always did think your system of perfect exclusion too severe but hoped its effects would soon expose its imperfections - the idea of having in sight & source of so many advantages and preventing your children fro enjoying them - it is too bad - I hope you'll repent and do better - feeding their bodies isn't all we have to do for our children - but & I forgot I must not scold this time someday when I get roused then look out for somebody else beside your very loving Mother     Julius' letter went yesterday -

Ma
Recd Nov 25. 
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois -

Dearest John - I congratulate you in your twenty-seventh (?) birthday - May you see many more - each one brighter - until the end comes - and may it be bright with the hopes of glory beyond.  I meant to answer your note and Julius' before this - but you remember what the copy books say about procrastination.  I do want to come to you  - ever so much - I would rather be with you than any where else now - I believe you do love me more than any one else - but the truth is I have not courage to make the move.  You will say I'm a coward - and I'm
afraid it is time but I can't help it.  I hope we shall see Jule - If I can summon resolution I'll go with her - not from a sense of duty - but for my own pleasure - Yours most aff - Jane

Dear Johnny -
I have this moment received your letter in which you are so disgusted - shame on you - what are you disgusted at - why at your wife's tender feelings, and you would be the first one to find fault with the worst of it in any one of the miserable sex - yes we must be very miserable indeed if we are to be governed & controlled in all things and at all times by the Lords of creation - you don't suppose we are made of adamant -do you - Well now in comment, darling, what does it all amount to after all you wished her to take a trip - and she finds she cannot do it - somehow, unaccountably perhaps even to herself - but still it gives her more pleasure to stay with her husband & children and as you wished to please her, you ought to be satisfied - not a bit displeased or fault finding - for love's sake don't scold - you have done right don't

spoil it all - like the java cow who gave the milk and then set her foot in it - these things will all dwindle into insignificance by the unclear of real trials - never mention it to Julia's mortification - I pity her more than I do you.  Love her the more, and cherish and encourage all such tender feelings - what is the world or your home without feeling - I know exactly how Julia felt - but then I am one of the weaker sex- yes and I think it is just as good as the stronger one and I don't believe but what you do too - and if any of your children do such things why just set them down as chips of the old block - now if I could give you a good old fashioned squeeze and kiss and have a hearty laugh - we would bury the tomahawk - And? Mr Hempstead married yet and is he as much of a yankee as ever - and as verdant - but there if he thinks you

handsome, he certainly is a man of taste and good sense - give my best respects to him next time you see him - Jane's note was to have gone in my last but I forgot it - don't you think I am daft?  upon my word I do believe this is my birthday - if I live 37 years more I shall be ?00  - shouldn't I - and if I were 100 how old would you be-  Well I guess I had better quit or you will come bolting down to see if I am crazed, once there it would be such a disappointment to think you have come for nothing - Oh then indeed you might be disgusted -  We are all well and send ever so much love to you all - it is my present expectation to be with Romaine in May - if this letter has any tendency to reconcile you to our poor sex, or provoke a smile of complacency it will have answered its end and satisfied your loving and devoted Mother -
Shall I get you the vinegar. Lacook? says he has good and John Baird thinks it could be sent by Wheeling for 1.50 the price 5.00 a bl-

Ma
Recd Dec 16. 1862
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois

Jane is too unwell to write this evening -
Dec 10"
Dear Johnny
I have just received your letter and will answer it immediately, lest I be overtaken with cares that cause forgetfulness - perhaps I should rather say neglect- well sometimes it is neither - guess too and you such a good faithful Johnny - but I know, too that you always feel that your Mother loves you dearly - and is always anxious for your best interests - do you remember a hymn that says 'strange that a harp of thousands strings should keep in time so long' - I realize this in its fullest meanings - the slightest touch upon one of its strings sometimes causes the whole instrument to vibrate for hours - without power to stop - there is no remedy but patience - the will has no power over physical inability - My health is pretty good just now but I feel that I have no stamina - a breath could blow me away - I could endure nothing - but it is well - the world, tho a very good world it is, has no attractions for me -

and tho I think as long as we do live we have something to do, yet 1 child will be spared - yet I enjoy all the blessings with which I am surrounded and feel deeply interested in the affairs of life - but feeling always that my Father's at the helm. I am willing he should govern - and I have no will but that his will be done and his Kingdom established - a Kingdom of peace love and freedom to all - for which purpose I cry daily and continually to the Almighty to deliver the captive and let the oppressed go free - not till then will war cease - I hope - As to, who leads our armies or what their numbers - it concerns me less than the progress of true and righteous principles in our government - poor weak government, always trying to compromise with sin - now by giving the wicked rebels till 1900 to cease from doing what has caused the war -if that were to be, I should justify servile insurrection - no, slavery has

saved the Devil long enough.  Total cease at once - God grant the rebels may hold out until the 1" of Jan. and then every fetter drop into hell for the use of its inhabitants. You will think I have been reading Parson Brownlow - I did read a past one of his speeches that is all - but I don't consider him at all orthodox- Well Christmas is coming sure enough and our children are beginning to listen for St. Nicolas' bells - you must read that to your children - I believe Willie had it for a speech at school - it is called the night before Christmas -  I am glad you take so much interest in your children's enjoyments - no danger at all of spoiling them that way, it is the way to make them happy and good for when children are well and happy they are generally good - it is allowing them to do wrong that spoils them - I go in for all sorts of innocent enjoyments as a people we don't have half enough

I don't believe in feeding children on 'chopped catechism and whipping them every morning' - I don't see why they should ever be whipped after a certain age if properly taught I mean a young age too -  Frank is well and I guess busy - Julius has not yet succeeded in getting a farm he goes to Wellsburg tomorrow to see Mr Kuhn - Annie is doing admirably working, saving, making all sorts of country things - in good spirits and now prefers the country, but wants to remain near here if they can - Mr Wills is doing very well - Charlotte will probably go on in Jan. for a month or two- taking Willie and leaving Fanny with us - Willie is much enjoyed in his studies, and I think will improve-  Pa is about bargaining with a man to erect a saw mill on the farm, and says he thinks he ought to be on the farm himself - Nanny sends you a photograph of her children - she is having one of herself so you see if you had sent her one of yours  she would now send you one ( perhaps she may anyhow) - much love to you & yours darling,  ever your own loving Mother

Ma
Recd Dec 24 1862
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois -

Decr 20"
Very dear Johnny-  I hope you are all well & happy and enjoying the merry excitements of the season Lessons of recreation are useful indeed necessary to all and should be encouraged especially should the poor & laboring classes be provided with relaxation and comfort. so the season of gifts is not to be overlooked - Our children, great & small, are anticipating much enjoyment and many happy surprises. it is quite long unclear to hear the determinations beforehand that there is to be no giving, except to the children, but before the day actually arrives, every one is busy sewing, knitting, or something - one is making a night cap, another a collar. or an apron or bowing a ribbon - but tho a trifle, it is something to please, both the giver and reciever - and then so many secrets are to be kept - and so many hearty laughs at the way Ma Keeps a secret which is not the best they think - then Fanny tells Grandma, what she has got for Aunt Sis

whispering very softly tho there is no one else in the room - Jane asked little Harry Lee what he wanted on Christmas - O said he, I have told Krish Krindle, and he will bring all I want and he would not tell her.  how did you like Charley & Sophie we think the picture good - She goes to school and is a very smart child - they both learn very well - Nanny & children spent a day at Julius' this week while Mr Harding went out hunting - Annie is sick just ow with sore throat brought on by exposure - as she very foolishly undertook to do her own washing - she is a little too ambitious - we are all to eat our Christmas dinner at Charlotte's - Julius has decided on having the farm - Mr. Kuhn tells him not to take any farm, unless money is to be made - he must do more than make a mere living - and he will help him do something in the spring - he may come into town - if so, they will board with Charlotte -

Charlotte will probably go to Washington in January - and remain with her husband a month or more - she will look about for a house, and if he continues to get business, and they like it - they will live there - Fanny will remain with us. untill her Mother returns - I hear from Frank every week - but he says nothing of his future - Some of our boys were in the last battle. Alex Hart commanded his company - the Capt being absent.  he has been in all the battles on the peninsula and all those late battles in Maryland - and now at Fredericksburg - without a wound  George unclear too is in the same Company- George Laughlin of Pittsburg is Bell Mc Kennan's fiance - he too is in the war  She speaks very freely of what George says, and what he is doing - and positively refuses to go into company or join any gaieties - while George is in the War -

I thought I had told you all about the vinegar - it is John R. La cook who has it he made of pure cider and it is in a good iron bound barrel, warranted fit to go to Chicago - as soon as weather will permit in spring - you can buy Christmas gifts for the children with the five dollars - and we settle the rest when the time comes - we are having the coldest weather we have yet had you have one of our men in Chicago - Tom Birch - all the Birchs' here are connected he is in the oil business and says he is making lots of money - wants Mr Harding to come right on and see him with a view of? moving there - thinks Chicago the greatest place in the country - he kept a variety store here and failed - and is in business with some of his friends - our merchants never did so much business as now - I asked you a year ago if Julia liked the Independent and would like it again - you gave me no answer I repeat the question - be sure to answer me before Jan 1" - much love to you all - and a thousand good wishes - yours very truly and loving Mother

Friday
Dearest Johnny,  I could talk to you an hour - but must condense upon a page - Jane has probably told you that we are just now enjoying a visit from Sarah & her children- she has her nurse too - Charlotte & babe on a Mary Cape? are here also so you see we have a goodly family to see to - considering we have no girl - ours having left us quite unexpectedly on Saturday - but Mary helps and we get along quite nicely - and Pa is quietly well and  pleasant, which after all is the principal thing - I am so sorry, so very sorry, he does not let Jane go to you we are all very anxious about it and very willing to go but what can we do, dear John - unclear he may change My poor dear Charlotte came home quite sick and feeble with a very bad cold & cough, and quite discouraged about herself- she had a great deal of fever and no appetite - We are doing all we can to patch her up, and Pa is gibing her medicine so I hope she may recover, but she has no stamina and can endure nothing - I told her when she went she might not do it and that it was at the risk of her life - you know she is not very prudent.  Why could not Julia come to us- we would do all we could to make her comfortable - I think it would be good economy in you to have her make a visit of 3 months at that time instead of later in the season - to all her friends - you could either shut up house or take some small family on board with them - we should be very happy to have either end of the visit - and I do think it could be a good plan  think about it  I suppose Jane has told you every thing - I am only writing to tell you how much I love you but a sheet is not sufficient

for that, and since I can do no more just now - receive the assurances of our strongest love and most ardent desires to serve you - I will try to get you the peaches- Rial? talks of going the first week of Nov. people seem to doubt it _  Ed Leet is just being buried On dit that he has left all his property (8,000) to Martha Morgan - with whom he has been boarding - Sarah Jane is not expected to survive him long - Very much love to dear Lula? tell her to abstain from tea & coffee & meat as much as in her lieth, and take as much gentle exercise in the open air as possible - plain & simple diet during the last month lessens the tendency to fever.  Very truly and affectionately yours
M.L.M-

Nov. 15th 1863
My dear Brother, I intended writing to you before Jane left you, but was lazy & busy - & did not.  I was going to remind you of the interest due me on the 1st Nov? & which I depend on for my Christmas money.  I did intend to ask you for 100 dollars of the principal to get me some furs - in case I go to Washington.  I have not yet made up my mind, whether to go or not, as the children are both anxious to remain here & to go to school, & I know it is so much better for them, that I can't bear to take my own pleasure at their expense.  If perfectly convenient, you may send it - if not, wait until I need it - I have been thinking of buying Julius's house - & in that case would ask you to pay me in the spring if you could, 1000 dollars but Mr Wills thinks Julius' asks

too much - 3000 - & so does Mr Harding & I don't know if either will take it at that rate.  Did Mr Wills write to you some time ago, about disposing of his interest in a Library? ( I think it was)  & can you do it?  I am to go to Pittsburg soon to get another set of teeth made - the ones I am wearing are called temporary though I have had them two years - Dr Ward is pokey & sick - but I think as they are paid for, it is better to go now & get them at once- Remember me to Julia & the children- With much love I am as ever your affectionate sister, Charlotte

May 16"
Dear Janey- I hope you have received my last 14" - and I think I wrote before I left home - you speak of a note to John was it not a lecture - and was there not a note for you - Sis is too lazy about writing letters- tho she has been quite occupied lately and now I suppose she feels very much burdened with the care of the house and superintendence of Mary to say nothing of Pa - then you know the grand concert - requires so much practicings but still I do think she ought to write to you & Frank at least once a week - do write to poor Franky, he says last week he did not get a simple letter - his letter to me was of the 10" Mrs Wade writes on the 14" that he was well & happy - for which I am thankful - Sis said she would try to write to you on friday - but why you do not get my letters I cannot tell - I did not direct the last to John, so he must enquire for Jane Le Moyne - I cannot go back and write

over again the same things - I left off wednesday morning - telling you Romaine had not been very well, had premonitory symptoms, but was a little better - she seemed pretty well all day - and after tea went to Mrs Letenouex? ! but returned with pains - which continuing the Dr was sent for - she was sick all night and baby did not make his appearance until 5.  what a long night.  we were all up - all night - I came to my room several times but what was the use - I could not sleep - anxiety kept me up and then the happy termination of our long night refreshed me - so after breakfast I went to bed and slept until noon Romaine slept too, and has been very well and continues to improve - has plenty of milk and baby is well and greedy as a little pig - yesterday I seemed to have entirely recovered - but this morning I took a walk with the

children, got cold and have been sick all day - I cannot tell you how weak & worthless I am - I want to go to you and I do expect it would lay me up if Mrs Murray were going a few days later I might go with her - I should dread going alone - Has M. & Mrs Butler called to see me - I have scarcely been out of the house - Romaine wanted me to go to the opera - but I cared not for it and had not the courage to go to town.  I have no desire to see or hear any thing - the grasshopper is getting to be a burden.  Nicolas advises me to sell my bank stock for government bonds - says he will take them and pay me the interest and I think I will do it- ask John what he thinks of it. Mrs Murray has your parasol - my dividend is not due until June, but I will try to send or take you some money - I guess R. wants to say a word or two - so I will give her the other side.  Much love to you all. your loving Mother -

Ma 1862
Dear Janey - Romaine intended to finish this letter but somehow it has been my letter - it is now tea time & sunday - and we wish to send it in by Nicolas in the morning - so I suppose she will hardly have time - she was up today for an hour & half. and has not had no sickness at all - the children have been very good.  Ellen takes all the care of them - and sleeps with them.  The first night Luke waked and reaching out her hand said is this Mama' not it is Ellen - she merely said oh - and fell asleep - and so they have given no trouble at all - Mary Dempsey has been away for 2 or 3 days expecting the arrival of her Mother with the body of her brother, Capt. Dempsey who died of a wound received in the late battles -  he was his Mother's only son & support. I told you about Mrs Wengel's disgraceful doings in my last if you do not get it.  we will give you particulars again - in the mean time R. says - burn his photograph or she has done -

Ma Nov 18 .1863
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois

Wahington Pa Nov 14th 1863
My Son,  Your letter of the 4th unclear - has arrived here after a trip to Washington Iowa.  I do not feel disposed to put any more money into those two Chicago lots - As property every where is now at high rates - it would be a good time to sell them. - Please inform me what price you could obtain for them at this time and if it is a reasonable price I will be very glad to get clear of them.  We are all as well as usual  Yours &c  F. Julius LeMoyne

Ma Recd Jany 5/63
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois

Jan 1"
Dear Johnny- A happy new year to you & yours - as much prosperity as will be good for you - and as much adversity as you need to make you what you ought to be - the coming year is doubtless portentous of great events - may you be sustained enlightened, and guarded in the path of honor, holiness & freedom - be not entangled in the snares of worldliness and vanity - dear Johnny it distresses me to think that you do seek enjoyments in the vain and silly pleasures of the world - and that you seem to chose your companions from the fashionable & stylish - I cannot think you are true to your nature when you do so - I was very glad to get your letter - I could see that the noble loving heart was there struggling to free itself from the trammels of the work and O how I longed & prayed that strength might be given you to throw off the shackles of sin & temptation and put on the whole armor of a high and holy consecration -

I have, within the recesses of my soul, felt hurt at the shortness of your visit and when I know how long you remained in Pitts and how very little your Sisters saw of you, and how for fashionably you were entertained - I felt stung to the quick and did not indeed intend writing to you untill my indignation was past - I could not believe but you might so have arranged it as to see a little more of your own people - Now Johnny, you know, if there is any thing I despise, it would be to see you affecting and following after style and stylish people for I do know that such things are vanity and vexation - I speak it more freely because I have often been very unhappy lest you had such a penchant - and because my great love to you compels me to be faithful -and entreat you to seek first the Kingdom of heaven - how can I go and leave you behind - come dear Johnny and bring all your little ones with you, for of such is the Kingdom - we may never meet again here - but

I charge you meet me there - I hear from dear Franky often he is well- for which I am so very thankful - he had received your letter - Mr Vinton thinks it would be a great advantage if he could mess with the officers but his pay is not sufficient - I directed him to give Frank my dividend (only forty six dollars to be sure} but Frank would not take it. but officers are not always good & temperate and pure so it may be better as it is - how I wish he were at home- I hope he may be kept from sin - dear Johnny how very sorry I am you did not pay Mr Wills - they really deed it - but your character has suffered so very much in that affair I forgot to ask you about it - but when you are making & spending so much could you not save that trifle - I shall be in the fidgets untill it is paid - he has not said a word to me, but speaks very well of you all and says he likes you and thinks Julia

a very good kind hearted woman &c - but I know he wants it and I can't bear to have you bear any blame - now you will think this a queer new years letter but you have got to bear with me I am getting ready to depart and must throw off every weight - and hindrance I have been greatly rejoiced in having Sis come out & join herself the church - it is something to declare before the world that we are on the Lord's side -  Julius, I guess will remain on the farm he has just returned from Wellsburg and will probably be married in the spring - if times are not too hard -  Brady Koontz is better and in his office again - Much love to you all from Julia down- I hope the dear children had a merry christmas - and hope they may indeed have a very happy new year and moreover hope I may help them enjoy some part of it - as ever your truly loving and devoted Mother -

Ma
Recd Jany 11. 1863
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois

Jan 7"
Dear Johnny
Your letter came today but too late, to take - to hurry off poor Jane for she was gone - yes she started this morning and without Charlotte too - Willie has mumps so of course he could not go but he is not very bad and may be able to go in a few days - as Jane was ready and had become anxious, she went.she will be a while in Pitts and may possibly visit Mrs Carrier at North East so you are not to meet her at the Depot untill she tells you that she will be there if we had not been so busy today we should have been quite lonesome today especially as as we all have just enough sickness to keep us severally at home  Sis & I are just recovering from influenza Nanny is taking it and so we are all under the weather - but we do hope to get better - I shall miss dear Janey very much - but I do feel that I

ought to let her go - I know she will be better and happier- however things about us are not so bad and I think in some respects will improve. Sis and I are facile and will reap any benefits that may come but Jane's impressions have been too strong she must live awhile under other influences- my dear good Janey has been sorely tried - but her character is deep and strong, let us hope 'tis all for the best - we all need discipline how thankful we should be, when it does us good - Jane went off in good spirits - every body was so sorry she was going, bidding such affectionate farewells, and giving so many photographs - and then the same everybody was so glad, one was going to have a nice visit - then there was no scolding or fault finding - not a word and we were trying to fix her up and make her comfortable -

Annie & Julius came in to bid good bye - Jane seemed very happy - so may she return - I will give your note to Julius when he comes - but I don't know when that will be - We have had the sad news of the death of one of our students - who joined the Anderson troupe this summer - a very worthy pious young man as most of his class who went with, were. he had ridden forward taken aim and shot a rebel, it is believed an officer when a cannon ball carried off his head.  it was a quick and I suppose painless death - and I dare say he was ready - he is said to have been very brave - if the proclamation had been issued two years ago, and we had had an army of blacks, how many of our young men had been saved - but the people would not have it so even now, Pennsylvania is hardly

willing for colored aid - besides as you say the rebels ought to be Killed don't you think a few of the Indians might be spared too - had they been slaves, they would have saved us the trouble of killing their masters - there is a rumor that George Morpon is killed - at Vicksgurg - this terrible war it shakes us to the centre - and I fear we shall yet suffer much - untill emancipation is more complete - thee should not a slave breathe our free air- O let us not forget the goodness of God to us dear Johnny - and let us serve & praise him continually - May he bless you & yours and all belonging to your ever loving Mother and forgive all her shortcomings & sins -

Ma
Red Jany 20.1863
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois

Jan 15'
Dear Johnny
I am very sorry for you and truly sympathetic in all your troubles - the only panacea for all the ills and trials of life that I know, is trust in the Lord, yes and it is always available so, my darling, try it - it is inconceivable what mountains of trouble may be removed by faith. God grant you that sweet experience - Another departure makes us yet more alone how thankful I am it is only temporary - and under circumstances of enjoyment - when I think of the thousands of heart broken and bereaved Mothers in our land I cannot but weep and exclaim 'Lover what am I that I should be so blest - O may God soon deliver us' - None else can -did you know Bowman Bell - who studied law with Mr McKennan - the son of Mrs Kc K's sister - he was killed at Murfreesboro and his Mother is almost crazy - he leaves a wife & 3 or 4 children - Geo. Morgan's friend - have great hopes of his safety -

Charlotte & Willie went this morning Willie seemed to have entirely recovered but it has been a very unpleasant day drizzling & sleeting all day - so I shall feel very anxious to hear they are well I do expect to be rather lonesome this winter - Fanny is with us and will be a great comfort and company - I am only afraid she will be lonely - this evening as she was undressing, she said 'tis so nice to be here, to be with your grandma' - she tired of school, so she does not go any more. Sophie goes ahead of all - she came very proud yesterday and told her Mother she was advanced to No 2 and was head of her class - no one in No 1 now but Annie McKennan ( Pauline's) there is no Keeping her back.  she makes funny mistakes in sound sometimes, - the other day she singing hosanna hosanna to the land of Nod - meaning to the lamb of God - then John Brown's pet lamb will meet him on the way - she renders, John Brown's pet lambs

are eating of the hay'  - she is so correct? giving all the turns to the tunes - it quite amazing - but if she sees you laugh, she flies at you and pounds away - and says you shan't laugh at her -  Maddy & Mr Langley came up night before last and went back this morning - Pa & they settled up all their matters to the satisfaction of all parties - Mr Langley offers to buy my house for 1800 dolls.  he rents it for 75.  Keeps it in very good repair and pays all my taxes - which sometimes amount to 60 dols - Mandy is anxious to stay in it - indeed it is very nice & comfortable now.  do you ever get letters from Frank - he is quite pleased with Mr Sargeant - Mary Ewing was married today to Henry Woods a young preacher located at Steubenville what I call a reception wedding - no invitations, but every body expected to witness the ceremony - sis thought it a very pleasant party- it was too wet for me to go -

I sent your message to Jane - Much love to you all - hope you will have neither scarletina nor smallpox as to mumps the sooner the children have them the better, only be careful not take cold and for the rheumatism - why suppose you try lemons - I hope you won't have a siege, but if you do don't let it affect your temper, except to improve it - if that can be - yell grunt & groan to your heart's content, but never, scold - remember Job and be patient if you get very bad I will try to play comforter - As ever dear Johnny your true & loving Mother -

Ma recd Jany 24/ 1863  
1800 x 5 =90.00 across top
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois

Jan 20"
Dear Johnny  I really hope you are all well again - we are in status quo and so reduced in numbers we seem not to have had time to get lonesome - a child is said to be a spring of joy in the house - it is a noisy bubbling stream whose music keeps one awake at any rate - Fanny is a very lively bustling child much spoiled, but with many good qualities - the first week, you know is always the most troublesome, but I think when she gets settled and into our ways we will get along very well.  a letter from Frank today announces Charlotte's safe arrival in Phila - she thinks of leaving for Wash. on saturday - Frank says he has written to you three times for money without any answer and he feels disappointed, as he had a bill at the dentist's and Pa's allowance only pays necessary expenses, if you cannot send him any let me know immediately I think I shall have some by that time don't forget it dear Johnny -

I forgot whether I told you - Mr Langley & Maddy had been here and had settled with Pa - Mr L. offered me 1800 dol. for my house do you think I ought to take it? and in what kind of money - there is a great rage for buying lands & houses now Nicolas is urging Julius to buy him a farm immediately - and go on it - he went to try to buy the old Leatherman farm near Canonsburg - which at 1400 dols. but the owner Moninger? would not say he would sell - Mr Ewing is to see him again - Mr E. thinks Jim Munce's farm that joins him - maybe bought - so he will try that too - then Nicolas wants Mr Harding to buy Hay's across the way - and live in it - but Nanny objects to the stairs that are so steep as to be dangerous - Julius & Pa were trying to settle or compromise their affairs - but Pa was not willing to give him but 400 dollars and a horse.  a cold that Julius has raised - so they cannot settle until the accounts are gone over, which Pa finds very tedious -

Nicolas is much interested in him offering him any amount of money - or the use of a farm on his own terms - if he could have gotten away, he would have gone with Jim Kuhn - to trade in sheep I suppose Jane has written you to tell you her arrangements.  It is so stormy to night I cannot send this to the office - and as I suppose I shall get one from you tomorrow - I will not close until then - 21? yes, a letter from you and all right - glad of it - but you are mistaken about Frank - the poor boy was thrown upon his own resources too soon - and he is independent - I am the same - I fear I should not be happy if I were dependent at least only the grace of God would enable me to bear it - Frank is generous - and not mean or spongy -  he will improve but I shall warn him against covetousness or love of money - he is compelled to economise.

I really hope R & Jane will have better weather than this it is terrible slushy - sleety, stormy &c &c Much love to you all dear Johnny never mind the democrats, we will use them up after a while with our regiments of blacks and the rebels too - I do believe you read nothing but democrat papers - I am still hopeful - the fact is we really need a most complete thrashing - within an inch of our lives - so we must take it - as ever your truly loving Mother

Ma
Recd Feby 5. 1863
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois

Feb 1st
Dear Johnny - I really believe I did not write to you last week - but I was too sick and too busy too - that is I was too sick to be so busy - I had a bilious attack that weakened me very much indeed and in the midst of it Fanny took the mumps and altho she is not sick she needs much attention, particularly at night and that robs me of my most potent remedy, sleep but we are doing finely - Sis does all she can - and I have a good girl in the Kitchen - today I was out, so I may be considered off the list -  I received a letter from Dr Naret with an offer for two of my lots - at 900 for one and 1000 for the other - very good offers.  the 1000 dol one is in what he calls government indebtedness at 6 per cent - but Pa refuses to have any thing to do with it at all

and will not say that he will sign the deeds - but says I may do as I please - Can I convey without his name - or could I convey all my property an agent or trustee - to be disposed of as in case of death by will - do you know the law in Ohio - I have deferred a decisive answer untill I would consult my children - so don't forget to advise me - I have thought a good way to dispose of the money would be, to divide it among my children and they pay me a certain interest - it would accommodate some of them - I think - the interest being low and to some nominal - at my death - they keep it - if all my property were sold and so disposed of I would have no trouble - Romaine expects certainly to start on Tuesday - nothing occuring in the meantime to prevent

I suppose Charlotte is in Washington City - all well at last advises - I wont talk war with you any more - you didn't seem to understand me - I will only say I believe as long as we have any slavery we shall have war and Sumner is one of my admirations - and Seward a traitor and I hope Fremot will go to Carolina and Stanley ought to be shot - quantum sufficit don't discount me. Horace's tribune - he is one of our greatest men - long may he flourish - Nicolas did not buy the house nor the farm -  Jane is having a delightful visit I am so glad and I do hope Romaine will enjoy her visit - Nicolas is a real good fellow - I hope you are all well and have neither smallpox rheumatism, scarlet fever nor mumps-

dear Johnny I am sorry to send you such a sorry epistle - and hope it won't make you sorryful - but the fact is I have not a dozen ideas to night - and then I have not read the Chronicle today  - and must see the news - so after giving as much love all the dear children as you think good for them, mind it is very sweet - why keep a little for yourself - from your loving old Mamma

Ma Recd Mar 26/ 1863?
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois

Mar 23
Dear Johnny
I wrote to Jane on saturday night - but that need not prevent my situation to you this morning - for the first week we have been enjoying the return of our absentees.  They all seem to enjoy home again - and Frank would like much to a month - and has so intended - but his commission has followed so closely upon his heels - he hardly knows what to do - but expects to hear soon from Dr. King - he is assigned to the 38th P.V. Col. Anderson - the 9th Reserve being included -n he is gone to Julius today - they expect to move in, in a few days - I charged him not to forget your vinegar - I will look for carpeting but do not think there is any to be had. rag carpets went out of use - even Susan Wolf told me she would not buy a rag carpet - if the war continue I suppose we will all have to come down a few jigs - but have patience - things are beginning to go just right.  the darkies have got to end the war - So you have a hobby horse, you could not have a safer one than Mac.  you are sure he will never run into danger, but always retreat in time

O well, poor fellow.  Many an other would have had his head turned - since I find I cannot change the tide of affairs - I don't fret much about politics - we are getting up some excitement about Union Leagues - the democrats here are of the Copperhead stripe and have carried the town elections, by greatly reduced majorities.  Alex Wishart, John Grayson, Park. Thompson and the offscouring of lanes and alleys - are all busy - But the Union League grows- Mrs Morgan died in the night - her children all with her- 
I am sorry dear little was disappointed give him a kiss and tell him.  I did not know he was so big and so smart - and I suppose I may add so good- as it seems to be conceded on all hands, they are all as good as any need for.  God bless them & you-I send something for the dear child and he will not again be neglected.  Love to all. as ever your loving Mother

she has no nurse and lots to do - while Mrs. Reed & I were calling the old man was pounding away at his room door as tho he would break it open.  They have to keep him locked in - I hope Mac is in better favor than his namesake - I always thought him an incompetent but I am afraid he was more - he is certainly a coward- well when we get all the darkies in and Fremont at their head we will take Dixie - Frank is at Miner's hill 8 miles from Washington - but his destination is - Assnt Surg 9! Res Washington DC
I am not sure that we have told Jane - he may be put into a hospital in Washington - Sis is very busy just now preparing for the concert - I suppose she will want to tell Jane all about it herself.

Our season has been very wet and backward - but a fine prospect of fruit much love to you all - especially the dear children - I don't know anything you can do to large tonsils, but try to avoid colas.  I dont believe you feed enough meat & grease to overcome scrofulous tendencies & developments- for which a rich nourishing diet is necessary - tho I do not think much meat good for children - unless in that care-  As ever dear children your loving Mother-

Ma Recd April 19 1863
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois

Dear Johnny - I received your letter yesterday always glad to hear from you dear boy, but must confess, yesterday's gave me much uneasiness you have been unwell so long.  I fear there must be some latent seeds of disease, that will develope seriously, unless averted soon - you have neglected your health too much - stop now and take care of yourself - it will be much gain in the end. of what will it avail your family to have a few pence more or less if you are prostrated by sickness or which you know is very possible, if you be taken from them - above all don't soak yourself with ale & beer, miserable make believes - only good while you are under their stimulating effects - you must not fear black tea - for I have never heard the weakest nerved people complain of it I drink it 3 times a day - just because it seems to suit my stomach - but if you feel a little excited by it - I don't believe it would hurt as part of your trouble may arise from the want of tobacco, but that will only be temporary - of course such a narcotic must have affected your system, and you are now feeling its deleterious effects-
